Sure, here are 20 items that can help clarify what it means to have common sense in sales:

1. Knowing how to communicate with different types of customers and tailoring your approach accordingly.
2. Understanding the value proposition of the product or service being sold and being able to articulate it clearly.
3. Recognizing when a customer is not a good fit for the product or service and being able to walk away from the sale if necessary.
4. Knowing how to manage your time effectively and prioritize sales opportunities.
5. Understanding the competition and being able to position your product or service effectively against them.
6. Knowing how to handle objections and rejections from customers in a professional and courteous manner.
7. Knowing when to push for a sale and when to step back and let the customer make their own decision.
8. Understanding the customer's needs and being able to recommend the right product or service to meet those needs.
9. Being able to build trust and rapport with customers through active listening and thoughtful responses.
10. Knowing how to use sales tools such as CRMs and sales automation software to manage leads and opportunities effectively.
11. Understanding the decision-making process within a customer's organization and being able to navigate it effectively.
12. Being able to work collaboratively with other members of the sales team and cross-functional teams to achieve sales goals.
13. Being able to manage multiple sales opportunities simultaneously without losing focus or momentum.
14. Understanding the importance of following up with customers after a sale has been made and being able to provide excellent customer service.
15. Knowing how to negotiate effectively with customers to reach a mutually beneficial agreement.
16. Understanding the pricing and profitability of the products or services being sold and being able to adjust your sales approach accordingly.
17. Being able to recognize when a sales opportunity is not worth pursuing and moving on to other opportunities.
18. Knowing how to use storytelling and examples to illustrate the benefits of the product or service being sold.
19. Being able to stay calm and composed under pressure, even in high-stress sales situations.
20. Being able to stay adaptable and flexible in response to changing customer needs and market trends.
